Posts.Content: Hi siani You'd be pretty unique if you weren't fed up! I was diagnosed in July and had snb followed by left mx , node clearance (it was in 5 nodes) and ld flap recon but no implant yet until treatments are finished. I find it really hard to cope with the emotional side and all those tears. I've never been a tearful person and my hubby doesn't know what to do. You def find out who your friends are. I have found a couple of real friends from acquaintances and been surprised about some ppl I thought were good friends who seem completely distant. I am sick of bein told to stay positive, that I have to fight it, that I don't look as bad as expected etc. I am just trying to get through it all physically and keep believing that I will recover and it won't come back! Having a smile face and being jolly is a step too far sometimes. Nobody gets the fear unless they've been there. This forum is a lifeline of people who completely get I and just try to help and support. you have had so much more than I have had to cope with and you seem an amazing lady. We all have the right to feel how we feel as it's mostly outside of our control. There are people here that will give you great support. Sending you a big hug xxx
Posts.Title: Fed up

Posts.Content: Hi Dawn I also had grade 1 tumours but had a biopsy ahead of my mastectomy on the 3rd Sept. I was advised that they would expect the nodes to be clear so I am keeping my fingers crossed for you. I was told that the risk of lymphoedema was low but I have been careful and seem ok. I had to have full clearance because there was tumour and traces in some of the nodes to am now being extra careful. As this is unusual I will be having radiotherapy and we are discussing whether to have chemo with the oncologist. My understanding is that they only take the nodes that react so that is probably why your surgeon took just one. I'm sure George's link will tell you more. You do not sound pathetic! I felt that it was just a barrage of information, appointments and procedures that just kept coming. You only had your op yesterday so will be feeling sorry for yourself. I am a big wimp and have been surprised by how I've coped with things. People say you just deal with things as they arise and they are right. Just look after yourself, cry, rant or do whatever you need to do. If i'm having a bad day i just accept it and know that the next day will be better. Sending best wishes and hugs xx
Posts.Title: SENTINEL NODE BIOPSY - PLEASE HELP

Posts.Content: Hi Linda, I had 5 weeks of rads and the tiredness kicked in almost immediately. The Onc said that it was not unusual and that going to hospital daily is draining plus the travelling and I had early starts for 8am appointments. I came home and put my feet up every day, schlepped on the sofa and rested. You need to be kind to yourself as your bodies under a lot of strain and needs its energy to heal. Apply the aqueous cream 4 times a day to help with the skin quality and internal scar tissue and keep it in the fridge so it's really soothing. I also got some weird internal itching and took Piriton which worked fine, as recommended by the radiotherapist. You'll get there! Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Radio therapy

Posts.Content: Hi Adriana I also had mx, clearance and recon last September. I had my node biopsy 2 weeks before so know what the pain from that (as apart from the mx pain) and I swear the clearance was worse in the early days. The other Angie is right to mention cording. Mine came on in November but gas all cleared with help from my physio. Speak to your bcn and ask to be referred for physio. It really helps bug the NHS seem to try to save on this area of treatment. I was told to stand facing the wall then walk my fingers up until it was twingeing, hold for 5 then walk them back down. Do this about 6 times but don't push yourself to make it hurt. Do the same sideways to get the arm moving. I have other exercises I can explain if useful. It does take time but you'll get there. Take care of you xx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hi RadDad. Sorry you find yourselves here but this is a great place for support from people who know how you feel. I had left mx, node clearance and ld flap recon in September. They couldn't save my nipple which also bothered me (almost as much as losing the boob) but it looks ok and I'm getting used to it. Misty Moley who posted earlier has a you tube vid of the 3d tattoo which I found helpful and may reassure you wife about options if it can't be retained. Funny the things that hit us hardest. I was all about the op and recovery and underestimated the emotional impact of this. I tried to keep it together for my hubby but it all comes out eventually. Just give her lots of hugs and reassurance. I was quite perky post op but really down a couple of days later which is a really common side affect of the anasthaetic so be prepared. Best advice I had from a friend who's wife had bc was some days are sh*t, just accept it! scream, cry or hide under the duvet and know that tomorrow will be better. He was spot on and it has helped me cope. This is a real roller coaster but somehow we all manage it. Word of advice, see if someone can sort out food for you. My poor hubby was working, hospital visiting and updating everyone then getting his meals. He looked worse than me when I came home! Lots of support is great but sometimes people like to be asked to do specific things to help. Also see if you can get a heart shaped cushion. It's the perfect shape to fit under the arm and helps you get comfy after the node clearance, specially in bed. If not that shape any soft smallish cushion will help. Hugs to you both and best wishes for Tuesday xxx
Posts.Title: Nervous huband

Posts.Content: Hi Gill. So sorry that you find yourself here but this is the best place for information and support. We all know exactly how you feel because we've all been there and that's really helpful. I was diagnosed in July which seems a lifetime ago and had mastectomy (mx), node clearance and ld flap recon on 3rd Sept. I take tamoxifen and start radiotherapy next Wednesday but didn't have chemo so feel free to contact me if I can help. I think that you are at the worst time. You're reeling from the shock news and waiting for results but don't know the treatment plan. It feels so out of control at first with endless appointments but you just need to go with it. It sound like you have good medical facilities and support but your sense if humour will be a huge asset. No, it doesn't always hold up but if you have a bad day just remember that tomorrow will be better. It is an emotional roller coaster but you will get through and we are all here to help. Nice to meet you. Sending a big hug xxx
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Thank you Dorothee! I was DX last July with mx etc in September and finished treatment in January. I swear it seems worse since the treatment stopped and emotionally I feel worse. Flashbacks, body image issues that weren't there post-op (I was really pleased with the recon having been told it might be very small) and generally fed up and tearful. It's like finally I have to come to terms with everything that happened in such. A rush last year. I swear if one more person tells me to be positive I'll slap them. A friend who's been there told me to write of at least a year and now I know what she meant. Thank you for your lovely supportive post xxx
Posts.Title: FEELING SO DOWN

Posts.Content: Hi Cbaz I know what you mean. I had grade 1 cancer so in theory the best type to get and had rads and tamoxifen. I am still struggling with the mental side of it. I think it only hit me that I'd had something really serious. Words of wisdom from a friend who is terminal... "It's not a competition. For each person diagnosed it's probably the worst thing that ever happened to them so is equally bad for us all". She's a very wise lady. Some people want to be in on the drama, some people just don't know what to do or say and others amaze us with their brilliance in this situation. There's no right way to feel and you're no better/worse than the rest of us here. Good luck for Thursday. I hope you get good news and need minimal further treatment. Take care of you xx
Posts.Title: Feel a bit unimportant

Posts.Content: Hi The vests that I've been wearing are the stay soft vests product no T613656. I didn't wear a bra but it was just too uncomfortable at the time. My GP signed me off from the time of my surgery through until after rads. I was very tired with the rads from early on but not everyone is. Also depends on how far you are travelling, appt times etc and your general well being. You need to look after yourself. This is a big shock for your body and in the words of my lovely GP "it needs to focus on healing you not work". Financially it's been tough but your health comes first. I went back to work part time before my GP thought me ready and have really struggled. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Hazey I had this about a week after I started in October. But it did ease off. I have had several really bad headaches lasting about 3 days at a time which the nurses say are migraine I haven't had regular migraine for years so I don't know if it's connected to the tamoxifen bug my GP is keeping an eye on it. Try to get Wockhardt brand as most posts on here say there seem to be less side effects. I took their advice and get mine from Boots pharmacy but worth trying. I've not had too much trouble so far apart from flushes and night sweats but not even this has been too bad. Good luck xx

Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Kath I don't know where you live but I had an mx and full node clearance in September and last week went to Rigby and Peller as I couldn't find any bras that were comfortable and fitted. They sorted me out with a couple of bras and a softie made by a German firm called Anita. They weren't cheap but the ladies there are all trained to help post bc patients. I now have an e cup and a b cup so very unbalanced now things have settled. Everyone has commented on how good it looks and the softie looks much more natural than the one from the NHS. The bra is style 5443 rosa faia and you can get it online but buy to fit your biggest boob. I was also told to go for bras with wider straps to reduce the risk of lymphodeama which I hadn't been told by my medical team. I've been living in m&s soft vests since I started rads but now the warmer weather is here I wanted to look more balanced too. Hope that helps. I think we all deserve a little comfort and luxury after what we've been through! Good luck xxx

Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge Like Dorothee I've posted on this before so apologies to those who've seen it before. I had left mx, ANC and ld flap recon in September ANC like you was exodus ting to have just rads so I know how you feel with the chemo bombshell. However, in my case the node involvement meant that my Predict results were between 80-86%. I was lucky to bad able to have an oncotype DX test. This is the test recently approved for the NHS if there is no lymph issues and gives you a prediction of the likelihood of cancer recurrence and the benefit of chemo based on your actual tumours rather than a sample. In my case this said that the recurrence risk was low and that because the tumour was slow growing, chemo would probably be of limited benefit. Based on these results I opted for no chemo but have had rads and tamoxifen. My husband and oncologist have supported this and we would have had long discussions if the risk score had been higher. I was certain that the potential side effects and the extended treatment time might be offset by no real benefit but I am very analytical and this is not an exact science. My onc's assistant find say that they tend to default to giving chemo because that was the norm. You may be able to arrange for the oncotype test to give you more info. Some people decide to throw everything at this and some limit what they will do. It's a personal choice and no one way is right. A friend of mind requested a second opinion when told no chemo was necessary just to put her mind to rest. Could you do that? Hope this helps. X
Posts.Title: Chemo decision. Yes or no?

Posts.Content: Hi Someone I know through work had the chemo and cold cap 2 years ago and didn't lose her hair at all. She is now back and well. She told me that it was worth trying. Good luck xx

Posts.Title: Starting EC and advice on scalp cooling please!!!

Posts.Content: I was told at my recall appointment that they were sure it was bad and that I'd need surgery. This was the day before a big family party and I've no idea how we kept it together and nobody guessed there was a problem. It was still a massive shock bring told I needed an mx. We decided not to tell anyone except my boss until we knew what was happening. I had to tell my family by phone and it's the hardest thing I've ever done and I've never cried as much as over the past 6 months. I'm so glad that you are recovering well and wish you a long and happy life xxx
Posts.Title: Thought i was going to die

Posts.Content: I've suffered with this too. Try the movicol or ask your GP for something as you need help but don't want to end up with a lazy bowel. More natural way is to add a spoonful of linseeds to food. I have a teaspoon in a bio yoghurt and they gently move things along. I was also told to take Actimel every day to counteract the effect of all the drugs on my digestive system. It's not fun is it!
Posts.Title: New Cancer patient

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy So sorry that you're here with us all but everyone is very supportive. I had a left mastectomy because the tumours were too close to the nipple and the location would have left a very deformed breast. I had an ld flap reconstruction (where they use back muscle to make a new breast) at the same time and am very impressed with the results. My left boob was always a cup size smaller than the right so it doesn't look too odd to me as it still is, although a little smaller. I am a dd/e cup which made recon more challenging. At the start I was desperate to have recon and look "normal" and my surgeon was happy to do this while it was medically sensible but lymph node involvement meant that she couldn't add an implant as I need radiotherapy (rads). Even without it looks ok. This is the scariest thing I've ever been through but your health has to be the primary focus. I would be guided by your surgeon but if you feel strongly about reconstruction as I did make sure that they know. My team have been great at taking my wishes into consideration when recommending treatment. Lots of people will tell you that you will come through this and cope. They are right. Somehow we all find the strength to deal with this roller coaster although it doesn't always feel like it. I am sending you a big hug and wishing you all the best for your appointment. Xx
Posts.Title: Round block mammoplasty

Posts.Content: This is such a lovely couple of hours. We had 4 therapists and the advice was great. My skin has struggled through the illness and treatment so it was good to get advice from people who understood what we've been through and the side effects. We all made a donation at the end of the session. I'm donating the perfume to our local hospice raffle to give a little bit back
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: Hi Rose I missed the earlier part of this thread but I wanted to let you have the benefit(?) of my limited information. A Breast cancer diagnosis is covered by the disability legislation and therefore your employer needs to agree a staged return to work plan. My understanding is that this would apply whatever your length of employment. I suggest that you contact either McMillan or your local Citizens Advice Bureau for assistance and advice. I have to manage on SSP until I am fit to return to work so completely understand the financial implications of this illness. Luckily my husband is able to cover the basic bills, etc so we are in a better position than many. I work for a very small business which can't afford to pay long term sick leave but from very soon after my diagnosis my MD (based on external HR advice) said that I am entitled to Stat sick pay (28 weeks I think) and that we need to agree a "return to work plan" which is currently based on 1 day per week for a couple of weeks gradually increasing to full time. She has been really great and had based this on the government guidelines etc. I also thought that your GP can issue a certificate that says that you are fit for work on certain conditions I.e. limited hours so it may ask be worth talking to them. It sounds like you work for a larger organisation so they will understand the risks of to following the rules. I hope that this helps you and Jackie. I send you both best wishes and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Dealing with emotions and going back to work its hard

Posts.Content: Hi Steve I'm also not medical but did opt not to have chemo. I had two grade 1 tumours and had a mastectomy in September but was lucky that my clinic is part of a trial so I was offered an oncotype test despite having tumours in the lymph nodes . This confirmed that the tumours are slow growing and that because the chemo kills cells that are actively dividing there would be less benefit for me. My understanding is that it attacks any cell that is dividing when the drugs are given hence the impact on good cells but any stray cancer cells might be inactive at that time and therefore not affected. I am having radiotherapy though as my oncologist described this as smart in that it is aimed at the area where the cancer was. It is a very hard decision but I felt that the negatives were not outweighed by the possible benefits. Very best wishes to you both and I hope that your wife is soon feeling better. How lovely that you care enough to post here :) Good luck!
Posts.Title: chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Diep is the tummy one. Ld flap is the back which is what I had in September. If you want to chat send me a friend request and I can tell you what it was like if that helps. Xxx
Posts.Title: Recent reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Tania. I'm afraid it's just a barrage of questions at this stage. I remember my head permanently spinning and did take the odd sleeping pill just to get a nights sleep. I know that's not for everyone and my GP doesn't hand them out line sweets but you do need to get a break sometime! Definitely speak to Macmillan about benefits or look to send if you have a local cancer centre or hospice as they usually have an advisor who can help. I'm getting some advice as I am coming to the end of SSP and have no idea what happens next. I don't get laid sick leave either and never expected to be if for 6 months. Do not let your employer pressure you back to work too soon. You are covered by the disability act and they have to help you. My GP is refusing to sign mad back for more than 1 day a week and only on a month by month basis so that she can manage my "back to work" plan and friends who've been there have warned me not tk rush things even if it's financially hard. I don't have children (that must be hard to deal with) bug do have a husband who has been amazing. You really find out who your friends are and there will probably be done surprises but let them help . Not sure why they think you're lucky... there's nothing good about having cancer! I'm not a group person either but have found great support and advice on this site and reluctantly joined a local hospice group which has proved to be brilliant and I have made a couple of good friends there. Take each day as it comes. You will have good days and bad days. Just roll with the bad ones and know that the next day will be better. It's a roller coaster emotionally which you can't prepare for but you can make practical preparations. I hog some good button front nightshirts and loose shirts for post op from Primark and m&s do decent support bras and the most comfy vests. Rant all you like to us. We all know how you feel. Sending you a big hug. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: 1ST Post! High grade DCIS

Posts.Content: Hi Kay. I had 5 weeks of rads and found the tiredness kicked in within the first week. I also had lumpy areas that hurt to touch and throbbed and the radiographer arranged for me to see the oncologist in charge of rads (clinical oncologist I think they're called). He said it was completely normal but to request a further appointment with him if I was worried. By week 4 I had a lot of pain and my skin was very sore but nobody was concerned and my GP told me to take cocodamol rather than paracetamol. I've still got pain now, about 6 weeks since finishing but still it's been checked and declared normal. My GP said that I've just been unfortunate in having a bad time with rads. I kept my aqueous cream in the fridge and applied it 3 to 4 times a day. My bcn also suggested putting a wet flannel in the fridge and laying it on the boob to take the heat out. I gave up with bras (I still find them uncomfortable) and have worn m&s basic vests which have very low seams so don't rub and they wash/dry in no time. My skin was close to breaking but never did on this regime. I would ask to see the oncologist to have it checked and put your mind to rest. Most people seem to cope well with rads but some of us react more and quicker. Sending you a very gentle hug xxx
Posts.Title: Pain with Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi. You need to get advice from a professional. I used to run but my physio and surgeon have both told me not to start back yet because of impact (I had ld flap recon, mx and clearance in Sept 2013). One of our local hospices had an adapted gym for cancer patients and you can be referred there by the physio or GP. The hospice that I go to is running adapted tai chi and yoga classes which are great. Hospice is a scary word but I am not terminal and didn't realise that they offered these services to those of us recovering! I have been told that lower body work is fine - walking, cycling and other machines as well as lower body weights equipment. My physio showed me how to do a Pilates sit up and I understand that Pilates and yoga are ok. The golden rule is that if it hurts, stop. I had rads and am on tamoxifen and just stop if I feel tired before I planned to stop. I think kettle bells may be a bit ambitious! Word of warning to Virgin Active members, I've been a member for over 9 years. They gave put up signs asking to be informed if there are changes to your medical condition. When I spoke to the staff I had a form to fill in but as soon as you answer "yes" to a question or enter any details they insist on a medical letter to say you are fit to exercise. I explained that I am not working /earning and that I couldn't afford to pay for a doctors letter and we are still discussing. I am furious! I have paid a fortune in membership and training and we have struggled to keep up our membership so that I could use the gym as part of my rehab. Seriously thinking of cancelling. My GP said she has endless requests for such letters from corporates trying to cover their butts and it's a complete waste of time. Sorry, rant over. I hope the info I've been given is helpful. Your bcn should be able to point you in the right direction for local services. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Joining gym after Breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi littlegem I'm with you too. I usually love Xmas but couldn't get in the mood this year and was glad to just spend it at home with my husband. I kind of resent that some of the things that are part of the build up for me (going into London Xmas shopping and listening to the carols from Kings college while making mince pies) just couldn't be managed either physically or emotionally. New year was even worse. Had to go to a fancy dress night in my in laws village. Just wanted to stay home not face people asking how I was doing was topped by someone trying to drag me out to dance arms linked round the clock tower then when I explained I'd had mx said she volunteered at the hospice and would look after me. Seriously, if I'd wanted to go outside I would have been with my family so I ended up in tears which was just what I was trying to avoid. Sorry for the rant. I have a wonderful husband and family who have been brilliant through this all but please, don't ask me to be uber happy and cheerful just at the moment. I had just a few lovely texts from some special people at midnight but am very pleased that this Xmas/new year is over. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: Bah humbug

Posts.Content: Hi vicki. I hope your GP has helped. I used aqueous cream 4 to 5 times a day but don't rub it in, just gently lay it over the skin. I found the texture of cream in tubes was better than the tubs. I've also used Moo Goo Udder cream which is recommended by the Australian cancer org. They have a uk website. It smells lovely and my skin recovered well post 25 rads. Take painkillers through the day and if you have nerve pain ask for amitriptyline which has worked wonders for me. Good luck. Sending you a very gentle hug xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - Help please

Posts.Content: Hi Just go with the aqueous cream and speak to the radiographers when you get back. I have used it for showering for a few years because of a gynae problem then used it for moisturising during rads and it was fine. I also used moo goo udder cream post rads and my skin is fine. Just home from 10 days in Tenerife with no problems. In fact the radiated area looks no different from the rest and I used SPF 30. Enjoy the holiday! You've earned it xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - Help please

Posts.Content: Oh poor you!!! You need to take the time and the treatments that you need to get better. I'm emotionally all over the place and we just have me to cope with. I also work in a small company and we are fighting to survive (i'm on SSP so also worried about money) so I understand your concern for your colleagues. I hope that they are like mine and 100% behind you and willing to cover for you to get better. I've been told of people who worked through chemo, rads etc, but my GP said that as a rule she believes that you should be signed off so that you can focus on getting better and reduce exposure to bugs etc. Breast cancer is covered by the disability legislation so companies have to give you the time off and protect your position. I know it's really hard when you are a loyal member of a team but you and your hubby are the most important thing now. I have had weekly chats with my boss and a couple of calls with the team. I've also said that unofficially I'm happy to help with odd things unless I'm really suffering. My boss really appreciated that offer and said that her business concerns would be mistakes because I'm not up to par and finding things that can can dip in and out of. It may be easier for your company to get some additional resource for the next few months than trying to work around inevitable absences. I'm sort of glad to be signed off as I don't have to worry about taking time for the various appointments and if I break down in tears only the dogs see - I'd be mortified if it was in front of colleagues or clients. This is a big thing both medically and emotionally and you are also worrying about and caring for your husband! A friend whose wife had bc told me that this puts work into perspective (I was a workaholic) and to speak to Macmillan or the local council about in avail entitlements. I wish I could just give you a big hug. Nothing worse than those days when the black fog descends but remember there'll be sunshine tomorrow. Happy to chat direct xxx

Posts.Title: Feel lost

Posts.Content: Hi Jell Firstly congratulations on your twins. I'm not medical but pray that this s just a post pregnancy thing and nothing to worry about. Just wanted to reach out to you.. 10pm on Friday made me think that you were in for a long and worrying weekend. Sending you big hugs and god wishes for Monday xxx
Posts.Title: New thickening next to mastectomy scar :(

Posts.Content: Oh Cathy, I know exactly how you feel. I got very sentimental about my mate Leftie too in the final few day's.MIT us such an emotional time with the shock, fear of the op and the tears but you will get through it. I am also rubbish a taking pills and can struggle with a tiny hay fever pill but I have coped ok. Tell the nurses. You will probably be on intravenous drugs at first but they can break the tablets for you if needed. I have soluble cocodamol from my GP. Don't worry, the hospital regime is non stop and the days fly buff take stuff to read. Rant all you like, we've all been there. Pack something silly like a teddy bear and a pic of those you love. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Upcoming mastectomy op on 18th

Posts.Content: Hi I am new to this site. I was diagnosed in July with grade 1 invasive ducktail breast cancer. I had sentinel node biopsy 20/8 and laft mastectomy, node clearance and ld flap recon on 3/9. It is hormone receptive and as 5 of the 24 lymph nodes had either tumour or traces I have been advised to have rads and tamoxifen. However, the need for chemo is not clear. In theory I am low risk and have major issues with chemo. I see it as non-targeted, brutal treatment which may not significantly improve my prognosis (I would have 6 cycles of FEC). My onc was honest that the treatment is tough but I am still feeling rough from all the surgery without launching into months of being poorly. I am really lucky that I have been offered the chance for a US test to assess the likelihood of recurrence but will need to wait 2 weeks for the results. Can anyone who has had FEC treatment give me any advice re the treatment and the risks of refusing chemo?
Posts.Title: To chemo or not

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your posts! We agreed that I would have the test (I think that this is the Onc DX test that the NHS will now do but only if there's no lymph involvement). If the results show low risk then I will probably not have chemo but any other result I'll be guided by my oncologist. I think that you are all amazing. I know that we have to just get on and cope with everything that BC throws at us but some things are worse than others and it has given me the courage to at least try this if it looks to be of benefit. Love and best wishes to all xxx
Posts.Title: To chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. Sorry you find yourself here. Lu's reply is spot on. You should be allocated a breast care nurse who will answer all your questions. If you think of things after you've seen her just give her a call. There is do much info at the beginning that you can't take it all in. Definitely take someone with you. My hubby came to my appointments and there were loads of things I missed or misremembered. I was told that I'd need surgery before my biopsy results were back because the consultant knew that even if the tests showed not malignant my tumours needed to come out so we knew what to expect but if was still a big shock. Let us know how you get in and ask any questions. We all know how it feels. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: Feel lost

Posts.Content: Russ Thank you for giving my hubby and I a much needed giggle x
Posts.Title: Saw this and it made me smile

Posts.Content: Please, please go to the local Breast Clinic. This was the only indication I had that anything was wrong and I lulled myself into a false sense of security. i hope that it is all ok. Xxx
Posts.Title: breast cancer concern, inverted nipped , GP says comeback in 3 mo...

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy. I found the whole lopsided thing much more of an issue now the weather's improving. No hiding under jumpers :). I got some soft vests from M&S and a friend suggested fixing the softie in with a safety pin for tha days when a bra is too uncomfortable. You may need to get a bra that's a size up. The only ones that didn't hurt me were a 34c where I'm a 32e on my remaining boob. I just used the filler to boost Leftie. I didn't have an implant though. I went to Rigby and Peller ((thank you hubby xx) and they fitted me with bras with wider straps and a bit of a band underneath which has finally meant I can wear a bra! You won't want to spend much if you're still "expanding" but if they have a branch near you I'm sure they could advise or contact your nearest john Lewis and ask to see someone who understands breast reconstruction in lingerie. Hope that helps xx
Posts.Title: tissue expander

Posts.Content: Hi Sorry but I haven't had this but I thought it was a newer way of trying to prevent issues with lumpectomies. You could call the Macmillan line. I'm sure there will be someone there that can give you some info or your BC nurse. If you need axils clearance I'm assuming that like me they found something fin the node biopsy. I had full clearance and mx but there was never any choice about the mx in my case. I understand the WTF feeling and wanted you know that we are all out here for you . Good luck xx
Posts.Title: IMRT - Anyone had this for breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey I forgot to mention that my husband rubs bio oil into my back scar each evening. It should improve the appearance but also the massage reduces the internal scar tissue. No idea if it is but quite nice to.be fussed over. I agree with Carole re how we downplay. I have a friend who has pancreatic cancer and when I said to her that I was lucky she said that for anyone diagnosed with cancer it's probably the worst and scariest thing that's happened to you so in that way it's the same for everyone and it's not a competition. She's a very brave lady who refuses to give in and is one of the chirpiest people I know. Your GP surgery should be able to refer you to a local cancer support service. I go to the local hospice who provide day support groups, advice, exercise and relaxation and a drop in service. I had no idea that they provided anything but palliative care for terminal patients. My day hospice means that I see a nurse every week and a chance to drop the facade for a few hours as we all know what it's like. Yes there are tears but I've also met some really nice people and we have a good laugh too. There's another service at the hospital where I had my rads so you may find a support group at your local cancer centre. Xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Gilly, I was determined to have immediate recon as I couldn't face only having one boob. That may be shallow and vain but the consultant said that there a psychological benefits to recon with mx and it usually reduces the number of ops even if it makes this one longer. A lot of my pain is from the lymph clearance as it damages so many nerve endings and the rads have caused some internal upset to the recon but this should resolve eventually. I've had little pain in my back ! Mistymoley has had great success with implants and a 3d nipple tattoo which she's written some great posts about. We all just want to feel better and recon is part of that for some but not all. My surgeon pushed for LD flap but it may be her speciality. She did a darned good job. Can you ask to speak to a second surgeon? LD worked for me but I freaked about the port for increasing the implant. At the time I freaked about pretty much everything! I think there are pros and cons with all and it takes time for things to settle. Let us know if you have any questions that we can answer. Big hug!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey Glad your appointment went well. I saw my Onc this week too. I have some fluid above the recon and pain in the recon which is being put down to radiotherapy but have been told that it will all gradually settle down. I saw a doc at our local hospice and she said to try up to 8 paracetamol and 6 ibuprofen per day as the ibuprofen helps with inflammation including that in the nerve sheaths which with the nerve endings get damaged during surgery but do heal. I believe nerves repair at a rate of 1 mm per week so slow progress. If this regime doesn't work then amitriptyline is usually effective. Since you're going away soon it seems sensible to try this sooner. I hope your GP has sorted this for you. I also asked why they don't say how long it really takes to recover and she said that the surgeons are very focused on the surgical wounds which are pretty much healed within a couple of months. The nerve damage and emotional side takes much longer and not really something the surgical team are involved with. My surgeon said about a year for the back numbness to subside but that this may never fully clear. Keep doing your physio as you can get muscle tightness and potentially cording later than I thought. By gently stretching the muscles it will settle down quicker but no strengthening exercises for a while yet as this will bulk and tighten the muscles. Do you have a Breast care nurse? They can really help. I know what you mean about implants but my surgeon us adamant that the flap recons give a more natural result. Well done doing the race for life! Have a great holiday and I wish you well xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Kat This is the worst time because you don't know what you're facing but try not to get too upset (easier said than done, I know) as you'll know the results on Friday. I was also told several weeks for results but they were back quickly and my consultant also refused to give results by phone regardless of the result. You do need some support even if the news is good. As others have said, if it is bad news the success rates are high and the treatment is all doable. I am a huge wimp but have coped with it so it can't be so bad :) Being scared and feeling sick is exactly how I felt and I cried loads but you will get through this and we are all here to help and support you. I'll be thinking of you on Friday and am sending a big hug. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: hospital called doctor wants to see me. scared

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey. I had mx, clearance and ld flap recon in September with 5 weeks of rads that finished in Jan. Im also taking tamoxifen . I was told that i would be ok to fly 7 hrs after 8 weeks but don't think I could have coped. I still have the "rolled up newspaper" feeling under my arm but that is partly from the clearance ANC I'm not sure if you had that too. I remember at 8 weeks feeling pretty fragile and I'm still tearful now. My back is still very numb, feels a bit like a shell, but I didn't have extreme swelling. I did get some fluid but was advised to keg it reabsorb naturally if poss as it can recur if aspirated. I had a range of pillows and cushions to egg myself comfy. You have been through a massive shock with diagnosis followed by major surgery and you need to give your body time to heal. We girls play down what's happening hug you need to take it slowly. George ANC Jackie are right, you need to see your bcn, GP or consultant and get them to check. I says my bcn a couple of times to monitor but had to call each time, no planned appointments. I was told that it takes about a year for the recon and back to finally settle so if you're impatient like me, we're going to have to take it easy. We're off on a 4 hr flight next month and I've been advised to take aspirin before flying, wear flight socks and get up and walk around as often as possible. Sending you a big but gentle hug. Happy to answer any questions. Take care of you xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey I agree that there is a tendency to give you the best case scenario, particularly surgeons. I saw a doc at our local hospice last week and she said it takes about a year for things to finally settle and that my progress is in line with what's to be expected. The surgeons are brilliant but very focused on their work rather than the after effects. You can always call the Macmillan helpline for advice or any local cancer centre/hospice. Take it easy, no lifting, lots of fluids and rest, high factor sunscreen and most importantly have a lovely relaxing time with the family. I was told to take frequent rests when out and about. Lots of coffee breaks and a sit down. Have a lovely time xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Don't be put off by my experience. I had full clearance as well. Your bc nurse should be able to put you in touch with someone who's been through it. The results are very good. When I went for my MRI one of the radiographers had the same op and was kind enough to chat with me and show me her new boob. It was really helpful and I wouldn't have known it was a recon. The surgeons tell you the heal time for the surgery but with any op there are other things to recover from. They will be trying to give the best result. At least with flap it's mostly your own tissue. Xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Dear Tracey Maybe he's one of those weird people who like to be close to a drama or think they look good by being with someone who's going through such a difficult time. Leave him in 2013 with all the other bad stuff and look to a long and happy future. Real friends are the ones that help you through this coz they love you xxx
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hudson, that is such an amazing post. You and Annie were so lucky to find each other and your love must have been so special to her through her illness. Keira, this is the level of person that you deserve
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: John, your post brought tears to my eyes. Who wouldn't love a man who said such beautiful things about them! Thank you so much for posting this. I'm sure I'm not the only one who was moved by such a positive view from a partner. Best wishes to you and your wife xxx
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon.. I had ld flap recon at the same time as my mx and clearance in September. My surgeon was concerned that she would not get a good result because I didn't have enough back fat but was also convinced that the DIEP would be problematic as not enough there either. I was stunned as I'm a normal size 10-12. I drew the line at them using tissue from my bum! I was set on implants at first as it was the shortest op but my surgeon said it would not look natural on me (Lefty was 32dd and his remaining pal is a 32e) and always favoured flap recon as they use mostly your own tissue . My oncologist asked her not to put a small implant in to balance because I would need rads. I am smaller on the left but I can live with it. She has said that they can look at an implant once the rads reaction internally has settled and can do a reduction and lift on Righty to even them up. She has also mentioned nipple recon but I'm thinking I may opt for the 3d tattoo as described by Mistymoley. The ld flap is quite an op but I am really delighted with the results so far. It's taken me longer to recover than I thought but I had node biopsy op 2 weeks before then the full surgery so it was a lot of surgery in a short space of time. I have had no infection or rejection issues and actually it's the clearance that's been most painful. Loved Rebecca's post about the things people say! My nicest was the nurse at my GP who asked me last week which arm she could use for a blood test because she had looked but couldn't tell which side was the recon. Just the little boost I needed. Also my rads Onc who called my surgeon to discuss treatment as it was such an amazing recon he didn't want to damage it. I hope that helps. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi kimlinda, not sure about brave but I have gone back for two half days per week as SSP has stopped. My colleagues have been great (we are a very small firm) but it's exhausting. The physical stuff is in many ways easier to cope with than the mental and that's completely normal. Hang in there and you'll get there. Take care of you x
Posts.Title: Brave people

Posts.Content: Oh poor you! I'm sure you don't look disgusting! I think that this illness shows people's true colours. My husband and I had a near split two years almost to the day I was diagnosed but we stayed together and he has been amazing. I do believe that things happen for a reason... we didn't split and I can't imagine coping with this on my own, I've realised how much I still love him, I've discovered a couple of new friends, I've realised what's important to me, our planned house move fell through last January but the care and treatment where I live has been much better than if we'd moved etc, etc. If your bf couldn't support you through this then he doesn't deserve you. Bad enough to walk away but to cheat on you really shows his mettle and you've probably had a lucky escape. I know it won't feel like it now but you will find the right person who deserves you. I am still crying and I haven't had the emotional upset you've had! I had mx in September with immediate ld flap recon. Because I've needed rads I couldn't have the implant but we've both been amazed by what my surgeon has achieved. I was a 32 dd before (32e on my remaining boob) and even without the implant I look pretty balanced in clothes. It's incredible what they can do and once you have your recon you'll feel happier about how you look. What goes around comes around so he'll get his payback. Just remember, you have a normal body, it's just a bit battle scarred at the moment. Beauty is you and how you treat people not how you look. Sending you a big hug. Xx
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hi orange tulip Sounds like you are really organised. I hope your drains are out. I felt a lot better and much more comfortable when I got rid of mine. Like others I have had some negative responses from BCNs re aloe, bio oil etc but was told last week that this I because they don't have any evidence that they work so can't recommend them although they are aware that a lot of patients say that they help. I was advised to check anything new that I bought to make sure I had no allergic reaction just to be safe. I've done this on the wrist of my good arm and have been using the aloe deodorant which I've found good. Before my first op my work colleagues made a basket of treats and essentials. One little thing that was brill was a lip salve. A friend whose wife had bc told me to always take my e-reader to appointments and treatments and that his wife watched films etc on her iPad during chemo sessions. Love the idea of the udder cream! I was also looking at the Salisbury NHS sunflower cream but will speak to my BCN about it but here's the link for interest http://www.mytrustylittlesunflowercream.co.uk/about.html Good luck! Decide about my chemo tomorrow but expect to start end Oct if it goes ahead. Angela xxx
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: Well done Cathy. Yes, it will be much more comfortable once the drain is out ( I also used to walk off without the drain bag), also absolutely normal to be weepy two days after op because of anaesthetic. Be prepared that you may dip again over the weekend after the "thrill" of being home wears off. Put your feet up and rest as much as possible so that your body can repair itself and recover. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: Home today !

Posts.Content: Yep same happened to me recently. I thought I was imagining things except I had the email telling me there was a message ;) Very strange!
Posts.Title: Private message

Posts.Content: Poor you Patricia! Some people just don't think about others and always ned to win in the bad luck stakes. Sounds like your mum is be of those. My mum and dad are 89 and live 200 miles away but they call me every day. My brother lives in berlin and calls weekly an is coming over to see me in november. my sister however has not called. Had about 2 texts and a quick chat when she was staying at mum's. last text said sorry but she'd got a dog and was very busy walking her neighbours dog too. Each to their own! Wonder if she'd come and walk my two mutts?? Look after yourself xx
Posts.Title: Feeling tired

Posts.Content: Jan My clinic hold a session once per month with a physio, bc nurse and volunteer from our local hospice. You are invited to go along (you only go once) but mine fell about 4 weeks post op. really useful but would have been nice to know some in advance. I found out that the hospice by the hospital, there a 3 different ones near me, is actually a day hospice and rather than focussing on end of life care has alternative therapists, advisors etc aimed at people who are going through treatment. They also have a course on life after treatment that is highly recommended. I had no idea that anyone did this as the other two hospices are very much for terminal patients. I didn't even realise this from the hospice website. There seems to be a lot of help out there if you look but by the time you feel like doing the research you probably don't need it. Everyone raves about the support line here and they were lovely when my mum called to talk and find out more. Will be my first port of call for general things. I think that the NHS has huge demands and different priorities across the uk and charities also can only cover certain areas or regions. I was thinking last night that we needed a survey of bc treatment and services. This is the first work type thing I've thought of in weeks so I must be on the mend! Xx
Posts.Title: Feeling tired

Posts.Content: Hi jan I am nearly 7 weeks post left mx, clearance and partial recon and waiting o start rads. I've start tamoxifen too. My nurse has rung me once but is very supportive if I call her. She doesn't call me regularly and says to call anytime but I don't want to bother her. She keeps telling me I've had major surgery but I've felt a bit abandoned after surgery. I've never had any big medical problems so have no idea how I should be recovering. I start physio on Monday which seems about 5 weeks too late to me and although they sounded nice said I was booed in because of a shoulder problem?? My nurse also mentioned counselling as I don' know how to get over the tears etc but she's not said anything further. I'm off work unpaid so don't want to pay privately unless I have to. I keep thinking that there are people far worse off than me but it is all quite overwhelming at times. My hubby's in Dubai for a week so on my own apart from the dogs just now. Re the gallbladder, my mum in law had hers out in November. Overnight stay and my offer to come to stay and look after her was met with "bugger off, I'll be fine" so we went for the weekend and I took cake which was deemed acceptable. Hopefully your husband will have a similar experience. When's your MRI? I'd have fallen asleep in mine if I hadn't been in such a silly position! Xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling tired

Posts.Content: Poor Jan. Siani's right that the diagnosis makes you more aware of your body and the stress and emotions are exhausting. You've had extra hassles and worries too lately. The feet sounds lie circulation issues - my mum gets this sometimes. Can your GP help? You are going through so much and am I right in thinking you hubby's been poorly too? Mine has been brilliant but he was ill a couple of weeks ago and was in bed all weekend which I'm sure was because of the strain. Just take it easy and rest as much as you can. I have finally given in and am a semi-pro couch potato. I do stuff if I feel like it and recline and nap when I don't. Call it practice for the op coz you'll need to rest after that :) I will be back to my usual 90 mile an hour self once this is over but to quote Pretty Woman, I am "vegging out, lying like broccoli". Take care of you xx
Posts.Title: Feeling tired

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat. I see you have stirred up a range of responses! This is a very difficult situation that we find ourselves in and I truly believe that there is no right solution. You have to do what is right for you. I didn't want chemo (not a popular idea with some who know me) but was luckily able to have the Onc DX test which supported my decision. My cousin who went through thus last year supported me based on her experience and regardless of my results. We are all different and must make our own choices. One thing I would recommend is that my mum-in-law made me a lovely heart shaped pillow which I have slept with since my mx, ANC and recon op. It had been brill at easing the discomfort and been a bit like my childhood bear by wag of a comforter. I wish you all the very best not least for standing up for your own way of getting through this. xxxx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Angie My local day hospice is running an adapted tai chi course which they will follow up with weekly tai chi/yoga classes. It's designed for people with cancer so I'm lucky to be on it. I used to run and do weights but haven't been able to since my op last September. Saw my surgeon a couple of weeks ago and asked about running and was told just to walk even on a treadmill but I had ld flap recon and I think it's about the impact. My physio showed me a Pilates sit up so I assume that Pilates may be an option. Her golden rule is no weights and stop before something hurts. I was warned that pushing myself would cause more problems and I also started cording after 4 months. For me it's all about gently stretching the muscles rather than building them. I am feeling so unfit from sitting around for months but start slow and build up seems to be the message. Good luck!
Posts.Title: anyone trying yoga?

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge I didn't have chemo but my pubic hair has seriously receded and thinned. I can only hope that they really did the rads on my chest! I asked a couple of friends at my support group and we had a very amusing conversation about this. Apparently it's not unusual although more common with chemo. Luckily mine does not seem to have caused dry skin although it was itchy for a while. I got some cream from an Aussie company called Moo Goo . It's their Skin Milk Udder Cream and it's recommended by the Australian Breast Cancer society. It smells lovely, is recommended for chemo and rads skin issues and has worked really well for me. I used it on my reconstructed and irradiated boob and body. They have a uk website so you can buy online and have a range of products for other skin problems. They also have a deodorant that can be used by bc patients. I also have the Full Cream product which is richer I hope that helps. Take care of you xx
Posts.Title: Lost pubic hair. Very uncomfortable!

Posts.Content: Hi Emma So sorry to hear your news. You have given me such great support and advice in your posts since my DX. I wish you all the very best and am sending love and positive thoughts. Not much I know but do know that you are loved by many who don't know you personally. The lambs were lovely. Ive only ever seen two born but it was amazing. We called the Bill and Ben and had to hand rear them. It was a privilege. My dream would be to have a bit of land and a few sheep. Sending you big hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: ESA (contribution based) is means tested in that you can't work more than 16 hours or earn over 101 per week. By going back to work I managed to exempt myself! And the gamut is pushing to get people back to work!!
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: ESA (contribution based) is means tested in that you can't work more than 16 hours or earn over 101 per week. By going back to work I managed to exempt myself! And the gamut is pushing to get people back to work!!
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: Dear all Since the NHS screen for cervical cancer annually (may be a bit out of date here) from early on I cannot understand why they don't screen for breast cancer from late teens to 80's plus. Given the genetic issues rudely it makes sense to identify this early and protect the next generation? If the government is worried about cost, surely prevention is cheaper an cure?
Posts.Title: Should we petition for routine mammograms to be offered for over 40...

Posts.Content: Hi Kim Poor you having this on top of the endometrial cancer. no wonder you are in tears! It's so annoying that they announce the test is available but there's a delay while they sort out the funding when people need it now. This is such a difficult decision to make. We have said that if I need to go with the chemo I would only do FEC not FEC-T and if it was too bad then I'd stop. I was told that the CT and bone scans don't always pick up tumours that are very small or rogue cells and that the chemo mops this up but destroys healthy cells in the process. As my tumours were oestrogen receptive I feel that the tamoxifen is a more targeted treatment that, with the rads, were the key treatments. But I've no medical knowledge so we think we have to listen to what the bc team say and decide what works for us. I am worried that I might regret this if anything else flares up. My hubby has been brilliant but it's hard on us both. We don't have kids (2 dogs instead). I think I'd be close to strangling a 10 year old if I was left in charge of one at the moment :) I could have killed the dog when he ran off last week and made me chase him down the road and into the field in flip flops, not what the doc meant by light exercise. Thinking of buying shares in Kleenex seeing the number of tissues I've been through over the past few weeks, Angela x
Posts.Title: anybody decide not to have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Kim I completely get where you are as I am in almost the same place. I had left mx, lymph node clearance and ld flap recon 4 weeks ago. I was grade 1 and was told rads and tamoxifen would be the treatment. I was then told that the lymph node involvement meant that I was also flagged for chemo. I am very anti-chemo because of the aggressive nature of the drugs and the effect on my body and my oncologist completely understood and was supportive of my views. However, he went through the decision tool used and explained the percentage improvement associated with hormone therapy and chemo so that I really understood the basis for the decision in favour of chemo. It increased my survival rate by 6-8% which made it a yes for the medical team but a maybe for me. I have been very lucky to have the chance for an Onco DX test which assesses the likelihood of recurrence of cancer by analysing your tumour rather than based on a sample of cancer patients. My hubby and I have discussed this at length and have provisionally agreed that if low or medium risk I will probably not have chemo but we will talk it over with the Onc. My hubby said that this is the biggest decision we have ever had to make but he will fully support me if I say no to the chemo. I would ask if you can have the test which the NHS has just approved to fund although I understand that this depends on your local health authority. Mine was part of a trial that my clinic is participating in. Re the weeping, I posted here at the weekend about being a wimp for exactly the same reason. Had a complete meltdown and could not stop crying from body wracking sobbing to general tears. I had lots of supporting replies assuring me that I am not a wimp and my BC nurse said it's completely normal. This is such a rollercoaster emotionally and I think sometimes you just have to let it out. I feel a bit better today but am sure I'll have more tearful days. I think we have to accept the sh*t days and know that tomorrow will be better. Sending you big hugs and hope that this helps. Always happy to talk if you want. Xxx
Posts.Title: anybody decide not to have chemo?

Posts.Content: Dear all. I am 1 year on following mx , full node clearance and ld flap recon. With 5 weeks of rads but no chemo. The surgeon did an amazing job but I am still lopsided and very self conscious about it. The whole experience has been an emotional roller coaster and a complete mind f**k (excuse the language) I had 6 months off work and a gradual return to work so I'm up to 4 days a week now. It's exhausting. My advice for what it's worth, take it slowly, cry, scream or whatever you need to do. If you have a bad day just go with the flow but remind yourself that things will look better tomorrow. Someone told me this at the start and they were right. The emotional healing takes a long time. You've had a massive shock, radical surgery and been thrown into a new and not very nice world. Don't rush to go back to work as it's very draining both physically and emotionally. I've also had to go back for financial reasons. I completely relate to what you say. Hate meeting people coz I think they all notice the change. Roll on autumn when I can get back into baggy jumpers. Dressing for the summer has been a nightmare with a softy that keeps feeling the need to look at the world. Over time it has got better but I'm not there yet. You'll get lots of support here as we've all been there. Just be nice to yourselves. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: Feel like a fraud on this site

Posts.Content: Hi Kay Unless you are making this up you are not a fraud. A DX is just degrees of bad news as you can see from other posts and I understand what you mean. I sometimes feel less "serious" because I didn't have chemo, just rads, but then some people I've met think my ld flap recon is a big deal. All ways round we are all facing a bad situation. Thankfully some are diagnosed sooner and have a better prognosis. I'm so glad yours is not yet invasive but wle and rads is not getting off lightly and this whole thing is a roller coaster which friends and family can't understand unless they've been there. That's why this site is so great. Big hugs to you. Xxx
Posts.Title: Feel like a fraud on this site

Posts.Content: Hi Louise Sorry you find yourself hear but this group is full of amazing and lovely ladies who will be happy to support you and your mum. The next few weeks are a whirlwind of tests and appointments but it's almost better once the actual treatment starts. There's so much info I suggest that you make notes. My husband came with me and we were surprised at how little info I absorbed and how much I got wrong. Take care of you xxx
Posts.Title: MOM

Posts.Content: Hi I know what you mean. While you're having all the treatment you're on a roller coaster but once it stops it seems to really hit you. Like you I've been told they took all the cancer and I just have tamoxifen now for 5 years and then something else for another 5 but I have really struggled with the emotional side if this. I go to a day group at our local hospice which has been really helpful. As everyone there has had or is living with cancer you can really be yourself, no need to keep up appearances and other people who've been through it have some really helpful suggestions. I also had to go back to work after my SSP ran out and have found it a real struggle. I am on a phased return starting at 2 half days a week but find even that exhausting. My GP is great and sees me monthly. I was worried because I keep forgetting things (I didn't have chemo which is usually blamed for this) and she said my brain is very busy healing my body so it can't do everything. At work they think that I am the same as before but just physically weaker but I feel totally different. I suspect that once I am back full time I'll look for something else, possibly completely different. I am getting a cotton mattress protector as someone told me this can help with the night sweats. Not sleeping is such a pain once you're working as you can't catch up or take it easy during the day. You will be able to cope but you need to look after yourself and not do too much. You are covered by the Disability Act so your employer has to help you return to work with a phased return etc. Macmillan have some great advice on this. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Back to work next week

Posts.Content: My 89 year old dad got a kindle fire??! He has macular degeneration and the ability to change the font size means he can read books for the first time in years. Why his IT lit daughter didn't think of I've no idea but it makes me smile watching him and my mum whiz zing back and forth on it. This site is full of lovely people :)
Posts.Title: Feel like a fraud on this site

Posts.Content: 3 weeks post mx I picked some damsons for a friend (physiotherapy I thought) and hubby took me round to see her and she said "you don't look as bad as I expected" when she looked an absolute wreck. Possibly topped by "well at least you get free prescriptions. I just had to pay 8 for a few antibiotics". When faced with the possibility of chemo.. "Well your hair will grow back" The current fave seems to be "well now you've finished your treatment your ok aren't you?". No, not really!!! I'm with you. I scream WTF internally daily . Today I lost it with 8 Mormons who parked in the middle of a parking area so no one else could get in. I think they decided that I was beyond saving. The Sky van driver behind me was laughing his socks off. And on the other hand, a lady in our village called me to say that she had heard my news (no idea how) and that she was there if I needed to talk or if she could help. She had cancer and knew how it felt. I was so touched by her kindness as I hardly knew her. People never fail to amaze and entertain!

Posts.Content: Yep, had that too. Only time it was ok was when it was the nurse at my GP who said "sorry to stare but I was trying to work out which was the recon. What a great job. You look lovely." I could have hugged her as I was not having a good day up till then.
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Dear mollydog I had clearance on the 3rd Sept after SNB two weeks earlier. I feel as if I have had a tennis ball under my for weeks but my bc nurse has reassured me that there is no fluid etc. I understand that this is all part of the healing process and takes some time. I was numb from the elbow up to my new boob but found that the feeling in my arm came back in stages from about week 2 or 3. Had to smile about the itch... I had the same and it s really weird. Definitely do the exercises and I was told to massage the area daily which did seem to help. I found that I would have days with no change then a sudden improvement in the numbness. However, I have found the snb and clearance quite painful which I'm assured is also quite normal. I am also due for rads but discussing chemo this week. I hope tat this helps.
Posts.Title: complete lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy So sorry you've joined our group but we're all here to help. This is the worst time. It all seems less scarey once you have the treatment plan and you are focussing on what is happening. The success rate with breast cancer is better than many others. Be very kind to yourself as you've got a lot to deal with. Try to make sure you do 3 nice things every day to balance out the nasties, cry, shout, do whatever. I'm an absolute wimp and I'm amazed at what I've coped with so you'll be fine too. Sending you a big hug. Take card of you xxx
